Introduction

Part I Histories of Whedon’s works: Politics, industry, art

‘Buffy is the slayer. Don’t tell anyone’: Creating a cultural phenomenon

‘How do you know what this guy’s gonna do?’: Producing worlds, changing worlds

‘There are so many things I’d like to be’: Multimedia polymath and mainstream cult

Part II Readings of Whedon’s works: Narratives, formats, characters

‘Someone else around who can explain these matters’: The exposition scene in Buffy

‘I love a story with scope’: Angel – cross-overs, complexity and conclusions

‘Come with me now gentle viewers’: Popular culture and (non-Whedon) authorship

‘Why’d this get so complicated?’: Narrative and televisual analysis via Firefly

‘I can bring back the world’: Dollhouse – narrating the tabula rasa

Coda: ‘I’m not done baking’

Appendix 1: Jane Espenson correspondence

Appendix 2: Definitive guide to Whedon output week-by-week
